HOLIDAY GIFT GUIDE: Poetry Edition

Many of you know me as a poet and creative writing teacher, but I’m also a librarian! Since it’s the holiday season, I wanted to put together a list of some of my favorite poetry collections to buy for yourself or a loved one.

I always aim to highlight the work of queer & trans Black writers, especially writers without MFAs, and writers from the South. Our work is not always uplifted in the mainstream despite us being innovators of genre and literary traditions. The poetry books I’ve listed here are appropriate for teenagers and adults and focus mostly on queer & trans Black poets.

Go to my stories to view the full post! You can also click the link in my bio and tap “PATREON” to view the full post. 

#PoetryGifts #BookGift #BookGifts #PoetryLovers #BookLoversOfInstagram #BlackPoet #BlackPoetsOfInstagram #LibraryBooks #LibrarianLife #PoetryRecommendation #GiveTheGiftOfReading #SeasonsReadings #HolidayGiftGuide

Tips on coming up with creative writing prompts for yourself: THREAD!

Save this post so you can return to it throughout your writing process 😊

1. Start with a piece of writing you admire from someone else. This could be a poem, a short novel excerpt, or a few lines from a song you love. The key part is to pick a piece of writing that feels like you couldn’t have written it yourself, because it’s so skillful & impressive.

2. Next, ask yourself what stands out to you about this piece of writing. Is there a phrase, a word, an emotion that moves you? What is it about this piece that draws you to it? Write this down.

3. Then, ask yourself what each line in the excerpt is communicating. What is the main idea being expressed in each line? How does each line build momentum until the conclusion of the piece?

4. Lastly, ask yourself: what prompt would produce this piece of writing? Remember, prompts can focus on theme, how the piece begins or concludes, what words or ideas get repeated, what types of figurative language to use, and the structure of the piece as a whole.

5. Did you do all these steps? Congratulations! You’ve done the hardest part: STUDYING YOUR CRAFT. Learning from the writers you admire doesn’t happen by osmosis—you have to deeply sit with their words, ideas, and beliefs. This is how you honor and learn from them.

6. Now, try responding to the prompt in your own words. If you end up publishing or sharing your writing, make sure you acknowledge your source of inspiration by stating that your piece is “after” the writer whose work you emulated. Most importantly, enjoy the process!

#WritingTipsAndTricks #PoetryPrompt #CreativeWritingPrompts #WritingHacks #WritingAdvice #WritingStuff #PoetryLoversUnite #CreativeWritings #HowToWrite #FavoriteWriter #LearnToWrite

REGISTER FOR MY NEW WRITING CLASS at the link in my bio!

I am super hype to be teaching a virtual creative writing class in the new year with @catapult. I’m a big fan of what they do & very excited to be joining them as an instructor.

HOW AM I SUPPOSED TO WRITE IN A PANDEMIC? 
Sundays Jan 22 - Feb 26
6 Week Class
$395
(Discounts available)

In the past two years, we have witnessed and experienced immeasurable grief. This is a gentle poetry course designed to help people write through some of the feelings and thoughts that have stayed with us during this time. It is designed as a low-stakes communal approach to writing when you don’t know where to begin.

Together we will study poems in the form of lists, short films, and live performances to deepen our understanding of craft. We’ll also discover the joy of poetry again through experimentation, visual poems, freewrites, and guided discussions. Course texts highlight LGBTQIA+ writers of color with special attention to spoken word poets like Imani Davis, Azura Tyabji, and Ebony Stewart. 

A class open mic is included to strengthen our bond as a class and develop connection in this isolating time. The final session includes a Q&A where students can ask questions about writing, publishing, and promoting their work. 

Students can expect to write 6 new poems, engage in collective study, learn about the professional literary world, and become part of a supportive writing community. This class is open to writers of all experience levels.

#WritingClasses #VirtualClass #CreativeWritingPrompts #PoetryWriter #PandemicPoetry #HowToWrite #PoetryWriting #WritingTipsAndTricks #WritePoetry #PandemicArt ##OpenMics #VisualPoem #WritingCommunityOfIG #BlackWritersOfInstagram

My poem “Aguacate” is an example of a concrete poem, which is a poem written in the shape of its subject. Please share this poem if you enjoyed it!

I’ve seen incredible concrete poems in the shape of a whirlwind, an ear, a heart, a teacup, a pair of eyeglasses, a tornado, a face, etc. Concrete poems are a fun way to encourage play in your writing, plus they are interesting even for folks who are not huge poetry fans!

This poem is from my book WE ARE OWED. I love avocados very much, but we only ate them when we had extra money growing up. This poem is an ode to the avocado as well as an exploration of the similarities between myself and the fruit 🥑 

#AvocadoLove #ConcretePoem #ConcretePoems #FunPoems #VisualPoem #PoetryForLife #HowToWrite #CreativeWritings #CreativeWritingPrompts #BilingualPoetry #BlackPoet #Afrolatinx

Who’s ready to take a class with me in the new year?!

I’ve been teaching writing classes in a variety of formats, digital and in-person, since 2009. It is one of my greatest joys. If you have the means, I’d love the opportunity to be your virtual writing instructor in the new year.

TESTIMONIALS:

“The course affirmed that my writing and my demons are valid, and that the stories that are most important to me are worthy of being written. It rejuvenated my belief in myself as a writer, my sense of urgency about producing new work, and opened horizons for future writing projects. So grateful for the space and guidance of an awesome facilitator!” - former student 

““I loved the focus on POC and queer poets. I've taken other poetry courses before that were great, but did not explicitly touch on many of the topics around identity and lived experiences that did come up in this course. Ariana's teaching was also lovely, thoughtful, deep, and overall such a great learning experience.” - former student 

#IGetResults #WritingClass #WritingClasses #TeacherFeedback #StudentFeedback #VirtualClass #HowToWrite #Syllabus #WritingTipsAndTricks #TakeMyMoney #WritingForLife #CreativeWritingClass #CreativeWritingPrompts #BIPOC

I believe in uplifting other writers and artists, especially Black, queer, trans, Southern, unpublished, spoken word poets, and artists without fancy degrees. I believe our stories deserve to be told. I promise to study your work, teach your work, and hold it close to my heart.

If you’re interested in supporting my work, the best way to do that is subscribing to my Patreon. My Patreon monthly supporters give $5 or more a month in exchange for access to my digital poetry chapbooks, archived video performances and lectures, new poems, essays, and artist resources such as advice from applying for grants and reading recommendations.

Link in bio. Even if you’re not a Patreon supporter, I’m glad you’re here. And I hope we get the chance to work together someday. 😊

#FreelanceWriters #SouthernWriters #BlackWriter #SupportWriters #SupportWritersAndAuthors #GoodSportsmanship #WritingTeacher #SpokenWordPoet #SpokenWordArtist #PatreonCreator #PatreonArtist

FOR WRITERS: 7 reasons you should read outside your genre, with some author recommendations at the end 😊

Save this post if it was helpful to you! Come back to it when you’re planning what books to read in 2023.

The main idea is that you can learn SO MUCH from studying genres besides the one you write in. If you’re a poet, try reading fiction and young adult fantasy. If you’re an essayist, try reading graphic novels and poetry. If you’re a fiction writer, try reading romance and sci-fi. I promise you, every genre has something to teach you if you’re willing to let it.

Image descriptions in alt text as usual.

#TipsForWriters #2023Books #ReadingChallenges #ReadDiverseBooks #HowToWrite #ILoveToRead #WritingTipsAndTricks #NewReads #PoetryWriter #FictionWriter #Essayist #BookRec #AuthorReading

This week’s writing prompt is to write a poem with the title “I deserve.” Then make a long list of things you deserve in the new year. They could be specific things like a food you want to try or more abstract concepts like peace of mind or justice. Play around with it, see what works for you. I’m Ariana Brown, a poet and creative writing teacher for the last 13 years. Follow me for more prompts and information on my next writing class!

#CreativeWritingPrompts #CreativeWritings #PoetryPrompts #PoetryPrompt #WriteAPoem #HowToWrite #WritingTipsAndTricks #NewYearPoem #NewYearGoal #NewYearIntentions #IDeserveThis #IDeserveBetter

“Superpower” spoken word poem by Ariana Brown from her book “Sana Sana.” Share this poem excerpt if you loved it! 

#SpokenWordPoetry #SpokenWordPoet #SlamPoet #PerformancePoetry #PoemsAboutLife #LovePoemsOfInstagram #BlackPoet #BlackPoetryCommunity

Some of my favorite lines my students have written:

“My love comes from my feet. It is a forward march.” - Ebonne C.

“If you want to heal, learn how to sing.” - Jazz Bell

“Praise everyone who tried on the slipper before Cinderella.” - Izzie Miller

One of my favorite parts of teaching writing classes is hearing students share their work and watching them hype each other up. I approach every class with the assumption that every writer is brilliant. When we learn new things together and present them to one another, we have the joy of witnessing each other’s brilliance. That feeling is one of the main reasons I love teaching creative writing.

If you’d like to take a virtual creative writing class with me, click the LINK IN MY BIO for more details.

Hope to see you in class 🙂

#VirtualClasses #PoetryClass #AdviceForWriters #CreativeWritings #CreativeWritingPrompts #CreativeWriter #HowToWrite #WritingTipsAndTricks #WriteBetter #DigitalClassroom #NewClass

FOR WRITERS: Why building your own writing community is more important than chasing fame, a thread 🧵

I often encounter young writers who are super excited to publish, tour, teach, and get famous. And I get it—writing is exciting! But we have to remember that if celebrity is your main goal, you might end up ruining your relationship to your writing. What happens if you don’t win the big award (even if you feel you deserve it)? What happens when you start teaching others only to find out you should have studied more? 

Humility is underrated. Being a student is underrated. Being in good relation with others in your writing community is underrated.

These are some of my thoughts on why building writing community is WAY more important than chasing fame, and why building community will sustain you much more than the pursuit of celebrity will.

Does this resonate with you? Did I burst your bubble? 🫧

#WritingCommunityOfInstagram #PoetryCommunityOfInsta #CloutChasing #FamousWriters #WritingTipsAndTricks #WritingSkills #LetGoOfEgo #BeHumbleAndKind

Remembering how to be gentle with myself, especially when I can’t write.

The pandemic has definitely lowered my ability to produce. Sometimes even when I want to write, I don’t have the energy or mental space to think deeply enough about an idea.
 
In 2022, my whole world slowed down. I wrote fewer poems than I have in years. Though I wasn’t able to write as much, I read lots of non-poetry books for fun, like romance, graphic novels, and young adult fantasy. I learned to make peach cobbler, biscuits, mac n cheese, and the perfect gravy. And I taught plenty of writing classes, which fueled me in other ways, and gave me space to get excited about poems again.

I miss having the writing bug. I miss being immersed in a project. I’m learning to have faith that the project ideas will come. In the meantime, I’ve been learning to enjoy what life has to offer between projects. 

Do you feel self-conscious when you aren’t making art? How do you cope?

#SelfDoubtBeGone #GrindCulture #WritersBlockSucks #Pandemic2022 #CovidDiaries #CapitalismSucks #WritingTeacher #BeKindToYourself #SlowingDown #GettingInspired

NDN Girls Book Club — Giveaway Unboxing

I am constantly amazed by what young poets are doing to uplift their communities. The amazing young poet @kinsalehues created NDN Girls Book Club to support Native authors and bookstores and build community. Go follow @ndngirlsbookclub! 

You don’t have to be Indigenous to support their mission or enter their giveaways. Please help spread the word about this amazing book club! Share their posts so they folks they are trying to reach can find them. Check out their recommended reads by Native authors. And send them encouraging messages and donations so they can keep this project going!

I simply commented on one of their posts to enter this giveaway and I was sent a FREE box of goodies including a monogrammed T-shirt and pencil, two books by Native authors, a sticker, a pin, and a handwritten letter.

Thank you @ndngirlsbookclub and @kinsalehues. I can’t wait to read these books and rock this t-shirt everywhere in Houston.

#NativeAuthors #IndigenousAuthors #IndigenousWriters #NativeWriters #SupportYouth #BookGiveaways

NEW WRITING CLASS ALERT 🚨 One-day, affordable class on using writing you already have to create a really cool interdisciplinary art project. Link in bio to sign up! Details below.

Make Your Poetry Come Alive: Developing an Interdisciplinary Art Project
Sat, Feb 4th
1pm-4pm CT
$75

If you’ve ever wondered what other artistic forms your poems could take or how to tap into your creative side when experiencing writer’s block, this is the class for you.

In this one-day class, Ariana Brown will help participants visualize how to incorporate poems they’ve already written into interdisciplinary art projects that can be showcased in non-traditional poetry spaces such as museums, theaters, public and social media.

Class includes a presentation on interdisciplinary art projects, (with examples of audio, visual, performance, and tech-based poetry projects), generative exercises, group discussion and Q&A. Participants will leave with feedback and a detailed plan to complete their projects. Open to writers of all experience levels ages 18+.

LINK IN BIO to sign up! Questions?

“Love is a House that Even Death Can’t Knock Down” original poem by Ariana Brown.

I wrote this poem in response to a visual art exhibition of the same name featuring work by Irene Antonia Diane Reece (@reanie_beanie), Jamie Robertson (@hernameis_jamie), and mk (@mnkndy) at the Lawndale Art Center in Houston, TX. The exhibition was centered on Black Southern mourning, praise, ancestor veneration, pride, and memory. 

This is an excerpt of the full poem. My Patreon supporters can watch me perform the entire piece and read along. If you’d like to directly support my writing, the best way is by signing up to be a Patreon supporter! Click the link in my bio for more details.

I’M GOING ON TOUR! Please help me share this post. If you’re a college student and you want @migrantscribble and I to *virtually* present at your school, tag your English department, student organizations, Gender & Sexuality Center, and Multicultural Center below!

The Kindred Tour 2023 is a virtual tour about race, grief, and queer liberation. Poets Ariana Brown and Alan Pelaez Lopez are offering their expertise in African Diaspora Studies, Mexican American Studies, creative writing, and cultural criticism through the following virtual events for colleges and universities. Each service incorporates a radical queer perspective on the histories of Black and Indigenous peoples in Latin America and the U.S., narratives of migration, building strength from our ancestors, and finding our chosen families.

We are offering:
—Poetry Readings with Live Dialogue
—Panel Conversations
—Artist Talks
—Creative Writing Workshops

For more info, college representatives can email Tyler at bookings@thespeakeasyproject.net or click the link in my bio. See you soon! :)

SPOKEN WORD POEMS TO TEACH FOR BLACK HISTORY MONTH: swipe to see!

I’ve been a spoken word poet since 2009. It was one of the first art forms I really fell in love with. Every spoken word and slam poetry community I entered was full of elders who reminded me of one thing: spoken word poetry is a Black art form. Whether you’re competing in a slam, listening to others in a cypher, or spitting poems on the sidewalk, the originators of this art form have always been Black folks.

In the U.S. in particular, spoken word evolved from African diasporic musical and oratory traditions. If you’ve ever been to a Black Baptist church or listened to funk musicians speaking rhythmically on their songs, you’ve witnessed some of the magic of this literary form.

Many of the popular styles of slam poetry and spoken word today originate from the Black Arts Movement poets of the 1960s and 70s: Sonia Sanchez, Amiri Baraka, Nikki Giovanni. These are the elders on whose shoulders we stand, whose pro-Black political consciousness drove much of their writing and activism.

I’ve compiled video links for my favorite spoken word poems exploring contemporary Black experiences--these would be great additions to any classroom or workshop for Black History Month. LINK IN BIO and stories for the full, clickable list.

#BlackHistoryMonth #BHM2023 #BlackHistoryMonth2023 #BlackHistoryFact #SpokenWordArtist #SlamPoet #SlamPoetry #BlackArts #BlackArtsMovement #PerformancePoetry #OralTradition #AfricanDiaspora

8 reasons why research should be fundamental to a creative writing practice, plus some reading recommendations!

This thread is a long winded and gentle way to say “everybody wanna be famous, but nobody wanna study.” I talk a lot about managing our egos, doing the reading, and being intentional about the work we put into the world. I talk about this often because the literary capitalist market pushes us to get famous fast, to sell the most books, to share our thoughts and writing before we are ready, so that the capitalist machine can be fed. But all of these things take you away from the joy and responsibility of your writing practice.

Because no one writes or creates in a vacuum. You are not the first person to have an idea. You exist in relation to a massive ecosystem of creators, thinkers, storytellers, and students. Do not be afraid to be a student. Honor your relations. Learn from your elders. Do the reading. You will only be grateful you did.

Full description in alt text as usual.

#ResearchLife #CreativeWriters #FictionWriters #StudyingHard #ReadEverything #AcademicLife #WritingTipsAndTricks #PoetryTips #ForeverAStudent #LifeLessons101 #ThinkBeforeYouSpeak #StayHumbleAndKind #RespectYourElders

This week’s writing prompt is to write a praise poem about someone or something you have a complicated relationship to. Begin every line with the word “Praise.” What are some of the good and bad qualities of that person or thing? Explore the nuance in a way that feels comfortable for you. I’m Ariana Brown, a poet and creative writing teacher of 13 years. Follow me for more prompts and information on my next virtual writing class!

#CreativeWritingPrompts #CreativeWritings #PoetryPrompts #PoetryPrompt #WriteAPoem #HowToWrite #WritingTipsAndTricks #ComplicatedRelationship #ItsComplicated #Complexity #LearnToWrite

A love poem I wrote in honor of my first girlfriend, “Sunday Morning,” from my first poetry book SANA SANA. It feels fitting to share on Valentine’s Day. It’s been awhile since I’ve had a person to share this holiday with, but I am forever grateful for the abundance of love I receive from my chosen family.

I know now that raw oils aren’t good for anyone’s hair, but I didn’t know that when I wrote this back in 2016 [wincing emoji] I just wanted a way to mark Blackness in this poem about allowing myself to reject heteronormativity and desire another Black girl. Once I gave myself permission to explore my queerness, I realized I could be much happier than I’d been in the past.

I think there is something sacred about queer love that is healthy (emphasis on HEALTHY). I still have hope that I’ll experience it again soon. In the meantime, I’m washing my hair every week, cooking meals I enjoy, and being present with my own emotions.

I hope you are loved well—if not now, then soon.

#LovePoemsOfInstagram #QueerLove #PoemsAboutLove #DreamingOf #DreamingOfYou #IKissedAGirl #Valentines2023 #BeMyValentine❤️

UPDATED TOUR INFO: Alan Pelaez Lopez and I are offering two brand new services for this virtual tour! While we still offer creative writing workshops, artist talks, and poetry readings with live dialogue, we are now offering panel conversations on the following topics. Please help us share this post to spread the word!

AGAINST NATIONS: A Panel on Black Futures from an Afro-Mexican Framework

Alan Pelaez Lopez and Ariana Brown will address the role of imagining liberated Black futures through the framework of nations, race, and gender. Each scholar-artist will present on the difficulties they face in imagining futures as Black people who must negotiate Mexican and United States nationalism, and the possibilities that open up when they betray their respective countries to think of a transnational Black politic.

&

WE NEED TO TALK ABOUT GRIEF: Race, Gender, and Family

Alan Pelaez Lopez and Ariana Brown address the following: How do the material conditions of anti-Blackness produce grief? What is the role of cisheteronormativity in the lives of Black, queer, and Black queer communities? And, what does it mean to have access to a safety net that is not conditional or predicated on the state, the nuclear family, or the law?

Email Tyler at bookings@thespeakeasyproject.net or click the link in my bio for more information on how to book us for your virtual event!

One of my biggest pet peeves is when people tell writers “show, don’t tell.” So many of the students in my writing classes have been taught that if your writing doesn’t incorporate tons of figurative language, then it’s not “good” or “skilled.” The problem with this kind of thinking is that it only values one type of writing.

Black women writers, spoken word poets, radical leftist writers, and working class writers have been stating things plainly for centuries. Because sometimes the stakes are too high to mince words. Because some of us write how we talk. Because some of us prioritize being understood over sounding pretty.

And of course, it is possible to speak plainly and still sound beautiful. The idea that there is “good” and “bad” art is a false binary. 

I want artists to free themselves from the idea that your writing HAS to be a certain way. The only thing your writing has to be is yours. Don’t let the MFA/professional literary world convince you to change your voice to something inauthentic. Study your craft, but do it your way.

#ShowDontTell #WritingLifestyle #MFA #AdviceForWriters #WritingTipsAndTricks #Controversial #MyOpinion #BlackWomenWriters #SpokenWordPoet #SelfDoubtBeGone

One of the best decisions I made last year was starting a virtual writing group with four of my friends. Every other weekend, we meet virtually for an hour and a half to write together. Last year we took turns facilitating generative workshops for each other, which was a blast. I teach a lot of classes, but I don’t get to be a student very often, so I am always thankful when I can learn from a friend. (I’m also really stubborn and not easily led, but that’s another conversation lol shoutout to my fellow Taurus people!)

This year we’ve decided to have simple co-writing sessions. No prompts, no guided facilitation, just five friends meeting up regularly to check in and work on creative projects. Every time writing group rolls around, I’m beyond excited to see my friends and write “our silly little poems” together, lol. 

Between this being my last semester of grad school, working several jobs, and trying to take care of myself, this hour and a half every other weekend is the only dedicated time I have to write. I protect that deliberately. And on the days I can’t write anything, just seeing my friends’ faces and supporting their brilliant ideas feels just as good. 10 out of 10, highly recommend. :) 

How are you sustaining your writing practice? Any tips you’d like to share with us?

#WritingCommunityOfIG #MyFriendsAreTheBest #WritingTipsAndTricks #LearnToWrite #VirtualCommunity #ZoomZoomZoom #VirtualArtist #Resourcefulness #StayingConnected #PandemicArt

This week’s writing prompt is to write a letter from your body to yourself. What does your body need or want? How has your body taken care of you? What has it witnessed? What is your body asking you to do? Play around with it, see what works for you. I’m Ariana Brown, a poet and creative writing teacher for the last 13 years. Follow me for more prompts and information on my next writing class!

#CreativeWritingPrompts #CreativeWritings #PoetryPrompts #PoetryPrompt #WriteAPoem #HowToWrite #WritingTipsAndTricks #BodyNeutralityMovement #BodyTalks #SelfRelationship #BodyNeeds #LoveYourBodyNow #LoveYourBodyChallenge #MindBodySoulJourney #MindBodySoulBalance #MindBodySoulSpirit #HolisticCare #HolisticArt

This is the only poem I’ve ever written in Spanish. It’s after @danez_smif’s poem “alternate names for black boys”. My poem is called “Alternate Names for Pelo Malo” and is my attempt to imagine beautiful phrases to describe Black hair in Spanish. We are so familiar with the negative words for Blackness and Black hair, like “pelo malo” (literally, “bad hair”). But what if it was described as bailarinas del mar (sea dancers), nuba despacia (slow moving cloud), or a tonada baja, cómo de la boca del pájaro (soft tune, as from a bird’s mouth)?

There is so much beauty in Blackness. I wish I had known this sooner. I wish I had been taught these kinds of gentle, loving words for myself, when I was growing up among non-Black Mexican Americans in Texas. Instead, I received the ugly words. This poem is my offering to Black girls existing in the same spaces I did, who need alternative words to name themselves.

I wrote the poem in English first, then did my best to translate it. I know it isn’t perfect, but that’s part of the process of returning to a heritage language that was lost in my family due to assimilation. And my attempts at reconnection, when done with Black liberation in mind, are my way of developing better relation with myself and my people.

You can read this poem in my poetry book, We Are Owed. Share it with someone who needs it. ❤️

#PeloMalo  #PeloBueno #Afrolatinx #SpanishPoetry #BilingualPoetry #BlackHairArt #BlackHairLove #PublishedPoet #HispanicHeritageMonth #Latinidad #SanAnto #BlackPoet

I gave a keynote last month to a large group of bilingual educators in my hometown of San Antonio. It was one of the most emotional, important speaking events I’ve done. I got to talk openly about how the anti-Blackness in Mexican communities affected my desire to learn Spanish. I also discussed how to care for the “outsiders” in the classroom instead of prioritizing teaching to the majority.

The teachers and administrators from San Antonio Independent School District were more than receptive—they were enthusiastic. They shared personal stories of language learning with me (both English and Spanish) and genuinely reflected on how to build more radical classrooms. We also discussed some of the ways they were already engaging in this work (and celebrating their students along the way.)

These moments are really why I started telling my story via poems. These are the kinds of connections I want to keep making. And hey, I’ve designed plenty of lesson plans and taught for over a decade…I’m starting to do instructional design and curriculum development as a side gig. It combines all my passions: ethnic studies, literature, and teaching.

Link in bio if you want to book me for speaking gigs. I just wanted to share this beautiful memory with you all.

#CurriculumDevelopment #Bilingualism #BookMeForYourNextEvent #KeynoteSpeakers #SpeakingSkills #ESLTeaching #SAISD #MexicanAmericans #PuroSanAntonio #Afrolatinx #Antiblackness #InstructionalDesign

Tips on how to build your own writing community: a thread! This is the most common obstacle to writing that I hear from students in my creative writing classes. And it’s real—many of us had in-person writing communities before the pandemic that have since dissolved. Many of us who are immunocompromised or still taking covid safety precautions are facing a lack of virtual options for community building.

In the midst of all this, I want to remind you that you can start your own creative writing community, right now. Swipe through for my suggestions on how to build a sustainable writing community virtually.

Reminder: You don’t have to spend tons of money and relocate to the middle of nowhere for an MFA, if all you’re looking for is writing community. You can create your own wherever you are. And the plus side is, you’re almost certainly guaranteed to enjoy the process, because you’ll be in space with people you already know and love, as opposed to strangers! Idk about you, but that sounds like a better deal to me. ❤️

Share this post to remind folks that we are still capable of finding connection! And ask your friends and peers to become part of your writing circle. I promise you, they’re looking for connection and support, too.

#WritingCommunityOfIG #CreativeWritings #StayingConnected #WritingWorkshops #WritingCraft #Critiques #WritingSupport #WriterLifestyle #FictionWriters #PoetryInstagram #PandemicArt #CreateNoMatterWhat #CreateNow #StayFocusedOnYourGoals

One of my favorite books of all time is Sassafrass, Cypress, and Indigo by Ntozake Shange. Most people know Shange by her iconic choreopoem, for colored girls who have considered suicide when the rainbow is enuf (aka the Black girl bible). I am a fan of all of Shange’s work, but I love her novels especially because of how poetic they are. They remind me of other Black women writers writing in the lineage of Zora Neale Hurston, Toni Morrison, Jamaica Kincaid, and the like. There’s a certainty that the Black female characters express about themselves in these books that has always been freeing and important to me. These women and girls know who they are and often bask in the pleasure of their own selves. I always say that writers should read widely, outside their genre and time period. Shange’s work is an excellent place to start. 

My favorite passage from this book:

“Indigo had always liked her name. There was nothing wrong with her name. She was particularly herself. She changed the nature of things. She colored & made richer what was blank & plain. The slaves who were ourselves knew all about indigo & Indigo herself. Besides there was great danger in callin’ someone out their name. Spirits get confused, bring you something meant for someone else. Folks get upset, move with wrath instead of grace, when callt by a name not blessed & known on earth.”

Who’s a writer you love and keep coming back to?

I’m hype to be offering another virtual writing class in April! Embracing Your Softness is a 4-week generative writing class open to writers of all backgrounds. If you’ve been having serious writers block, this is a great low-stakes supportive class to join.

LINK IN BIO & in stories to sign up.

The world we live in is structured by systems of violence that teach us to harden ourselves to survive. In this class we will “embrace our softness” by defining the kind of people we want to be, making room for the inner child in you, and engaging in a supportive writing community to help us deeply connect with one another. I teach from a Black feminist perspective, meaning I invite you to be vulnerable with me, while I do my best to protect you as a student and facilitate a supportive, challenging learning environment. This is a creative writing class focused on poetry, but writers of all backgrounds ages 18+ are welcome.

You can sign up for classes at the link in my bio. It costs $185 for the full class, which is less than half the cost of the previous class taught! Closed captioning provided via Zoom and the class includes breaks, a written syllabus, readings, discussion, writing time, sharing, and Q&A.

Any questions?

Today’s writing tip, especially if you have writer’s block, is to come up with a way to thank yourself for attempting to write! Even if you feel like you’re writing the worst garbage in the world. Find a mantra you can repeat to thank yourself for trying anyway. Say “I am grateful for the chance to write. I am grateful for my own mind. The words will be there next time.” Or whatever feels good to you. I’m Ariana Brown, a poet and creative writing teacher of 13 years. Swipe to see some poems from my zine! A year ago, I released a digital poetry zine about the worst breakup of my life. It was my way of processing the end of a three-year relationship with someone I thought I’d be with for a very long time. If you also dated & loved & lived with & got your heart broken by a partner during the start of the pandemic, MY HEART GOES OUT TO YOU. NO ONE KNOWS OUR SUFFERING BUT US.

These poems hold a special place in my heart because they helped me survive. They are proof that I still know how to care for myself, that I still have language for what has happened to me, and that despite the hurt, I can still create beautiful things. Since it’s the one-year anniversary of the zine, for the month of April, I’m lowering the price to $10!

Today’s writing prompt is to make a list of all the impossible things that you’ve done. They could be big things like surviving that breakup you didn’t think you’d survive, or smaller things like getting out of bed. Maybe that felt impossible, but you did it. Then, write a poem about how it felt to do that impossible thing. Because I bet you’re a lot stronger than you give yourself credit for. I’m Ariana, a poet and creative writing teacher of 13 years. My foundational degrees are in African Diaspora Studies and Mexican American Studies. When I tweet about the violence and anti-Blackness of Mexican history, I’m not just stating my personal feelings. This is based on years of research, reading/studying, lived experience, and being in community with folks who teach me to interrogate all of my inherited beliefs.

If you want to learn more about the history I discuss in this thread, check out the reading recommendations on the last couple slides. I also highly recommend signing up for virtual classes with @diasporadash and @famu512! Their combined expertise on Black Latin American history and informative teaching style is EVERYTHING. And their class on Texas/Mexico Entanglements will change your life, especially if you are a Gloria Anzaldúa stan or a Chican@ Studies fan. We have so much to learn from the folks intentionally erased from that field of study. 

We ALL need to be more intentional and ethical about our relationships to nationalism, patriotism, and the most vulnerable communities in our home countries.

#StirringThePot #HispanicHeritage #Mexicanidad #HistoryBuffs #EthnicStudies #BlackStudies #Blaxican #IdentityPolitics #Afromexican #Afrolatinx

There are lots of reasons why writers shouldn’t ask for feedback. Obviously I don’t think this is the case all the time, as helpful critique from trusted individuals can be useful! 

But in my 13 years of teaching creative writing, I have found that usually when folks ask for feedback, they should be asking for SUPPORT or PRAISE instead. Asking for feedback opens you up to the possibility of someone handling you carelessly at your most vulnerable moment—when you’ve shared something you’ve created with your whole heart. 

I tend to be really careful these days about who & when I ask for feedback on my work. I’ve done enough deep study & learning that I can tell when a piece of my writing is done, when I’m satisfied, and when I still need to work out the kinks. I usually only ask for feedback after I’ve done as much work as I can by myself, because I’ve developed a deep trust in my own intuition and skills.

I just want folks to be more careful about letting folks pick apart your precious creations. Because you probably know more than you give yourself credit for.

LINK IN BIO to sign up for a RARE  virtual poetry workshop I’m teaching in June, in which I facilitate intentional critique and a supportive learning environment, where you can bring your unfinished work and receive kind, thoughtful assistance on how to strengthen your poems. I almost never give in-depth, one-on-one feedback in my classes because it’s hard to do it well, and it matters to me to get it right. So if that sounds like what you’re looking for, hit the link in my bio. Deadline to apply is April 30.

Gentle reminders for writers & artists, especially folks struggling with their creative practice for any reason 💜 

We can get so caught up in trying to “make” that we don’t give ourselves enough compassion. You are a human being, not a machine. None of us are designed to produce 100% of the time. And yet, we often give in to self-doubt, the pressures of capitalism and ableism, the grind mentality that tells us we should be breaking our backs or otherwise we’re not “real” artists.

I was lucky enough to have mentors and a strong enough sense of self that I have learned to quiet that inner monologue that tells me to overwork myself. I have gotten better at learning my own needs and patterns. I trust myself and my writing practice, now. I didn’t always know how to, though, so I figured I’d develop a class to share what’s worked for me.

A lot of self-help advice is ableist and feeds into notions of hyper productivity. I have learned so much from disabled and neurodivergent therapists and teachers who offer practical strategies for coping with various obstacles. I try to take a similar approach in my teaching, because everyone’s brain and experiences are different, and sometimes we need creative solutions to creative problems.

Share the reminders that resonate with you. And hit the link in my bio if you want more info on my summer class. 💙

#SustainabilityTips #WritingTipsAndTricks #ArtisticWriters #AffirmationsForLife #LifelongLearners #VirtualClass #CreativeWriters #SelfDoubtBeGone #WritersBlockSucks #WritingInspo #TimeManagementSkills #WritingCareer

30, flirty, & thriving ✨

I spent a good chunk of last week celebrating my 30th birthday with some of my oldest friends in Oakland. I’m so grateful to everyone for testing beforehand, wearing masks with me, and committing to keeping each other safe. This was my first plane trip since the pandemic began and I only felt safe doing it because my friends committed to keeping us all safe.

I am entering the happiest part of my life so far and I couldn’t think of a better way to celebrate than with friends I haven’t seen in almost a decade. I spent the week thrifting, shopping used bookstores, eating dessert, enjoying an *actually* walkable city, reading poems, and reconnecting with my people. 

Thank you especially to @migrantscribble for hosting me and to the incomparable @natashahuey and @gabrielmcortez for planning a covid-conscious house party for me that brought together so many lovely lovely people. I hope I get to see and talk with all of you more soon 💕

#Dirty30s #OaklandCalifornia #BestBirthdayEver #SoManyCupcakes #Sunshine☀️ #CovidSafety #MyFriendsAreTheBest

I love being a writer, but I don’t love typical writing advice. Tips like “write every day” are not helpful for a lot of people. Often, advice boils down to “suck it up and just do it,” which ends up making people feel ashamed or unworthy when they can’t just power through. 

I’d like to imagine that there are practical, flexible strategies for building a writing practice that works for you. Strategies that take into account the different ways brains can work and various kinds of limitations or lifestyles. What if you enjoyed your writing practice? What if you took the pressure off yourself to be perfect? What if you accepted your limitations and made a writing plan that worked with them, not against them?

Obviously this is easier said than done. But if you’d like some practical, compassionate tools, a community to try them out with, and some gentle guidance, I’ve been working on a class just for you.

LINK IN BIO to sign up for my 8-week virtual class, Building a Sustainable Writing Practice. All sessions will be recorded and available for a month after class ends. There is minimal homework and I am providing homework summaries, so if you are busy or can’t complete the readings, you can still get the information! Open to writers of all genres ages 18+.

I’m trying my best to accommodate as many different types of learning styles as possible, because the more I teach the more I realize just how unique our brains are. The ways we approach writing should reflect that, too.

6 Holistic Writing Practices: the stuff people should’ve told you, but probably didn’t!

Writing is such a long and personal process, but folks rarely discuss how to do it sustainably. What if your writing practice was enjoyable, strategic, flexible, and accommodating to your needs? What if you gave yourself permission to incorporate rest, pleasure, and systems that work for you?

I constantly find that writers do not know how to be kind to themselves while still getting the work done. This breaks my heart over and over again, because we shouldn’t have to be hard on ourselves while doing the thing we love most.

We need a LOT more transparency and kind guidance in this field. I am doing my best to correct some of the faulty belief systems I inherited about writing, because I want to write for my whole life, and I want to get better at enjoying every aspect of it.

LINK IN BIO to sign up for my email list, so you’ll be notified when my MENTORSHIP services become available 😊 Soon come!

#WritingTipsAndTricks #WritingForLife #WritingForFun #WritersAdvice #WritingMentor #RestMore #BeIntentionalEveryday #WritersCommunityOfIG #PoetryCommunityOfInsta

5 Questions to Ask Yourself as a Writer: because you should do everything with intention!

It is so easy to fall into the trap of jealousy, insecurity, and self-doubt as a writer. The capitalist system within which we live encourages us to emphasize PRODUCT over PROCESS and RESULTS over RELATIONSHIPS. And honestly, I’m sick of it.

I want to know: are you okay while you’re writing? Do you feel good about yourself and your work? Do you have a strong sense of who you are *outside* of anyone’s idea of “success” or “talent”?

Idk, maybe it sounds like I’m repeating myself a lot. I learned a lot of these lessons later in my writing journey, but I wish I’d learned them a lot sooner. It would have prevented so much negative self-talk. I try to be open about these kinds of things because all of us get sucked into the capitalist machine at some point. And I just want to remind you that if you never become famous, if you never publish a book, if you keep writing simply as a hobby and nothing else, you are still a worthy and incredible human being.

Is any of this resonating with you? Don’t play like I’m talking to myself now!

#WritingMentor #CreativesOfIG #CreativesOfColor #WritingTipsAndTricks #AdviceForWriters #CapitalismSucks #WriterForLife

Tips for revising!! The worst part of writing, if you ask me! 

I get lots of questions about how to know when a poem or body of work is finished. My answer is usually “it depends.” It’s important to identify your goals for each piece of writing, and if you’re working on a manuscript, it’s important to pay attention to how each poem in the book contributes to an overall narrative, mood, or concept. There are so many little decisions that can change how someone experiences your writing!

I lost my dad before I got the chance to know him. Poetry is one of the ways I have managed to stay connected to this memory and make sense of the grief, which is lifelong and ever changing. 

This poem excerpt is from my poem “Death Poem” in my book Sana Sana. In this poem, I wrestle with my own ideas of what “should” be and try to make peace with what “is.” 

Everyone who leaves us, leaves too early. Whether you had one important moment with someone or one million, there’s rarely a time when losing someone feels okay. 

For anyone struggling with loss right now, maybe it helps to know: one of the biggest sources of peace and meaning-making is creating. Make doodle art. Write a poem or journal entry. Make a dessert or a card or a sweater for someone. It is how I stay grounded and reminded of how beautiful life can be, especially in the moments when I believe I have lost too much.

What has helped you while you’ve grieved?

#PoemsAboutLife #GriefAndHealing #GrievingDaughter #GroundingMyself #PoetryForLife #WritingCommunityOfIG

I’ve seen a lot of folks choose the wrong mentor or MFA program, and it’s the most heartbreaking thing because it can really mess up your relationship with your writing.

I tell my students often that “Your job is to protect your writing.” Yes, be humble and willing to learn, of course. But be careful who you let near your work. Are they trustworthy? Will they treat it with care?

My work has been mistreated by so many people, I go out of my way to ensure that I do not replicate those patterns with my students and mentees. I’m certainly not perfect, but it’s important to me that you maintain a healthy relationship with your writing (and your writing practice)!

DM me or comment below if you’re interested in working with me to meet your writing goals and improve your writing practice. I’d love to work with you 😊

"Dear Texas" by Ariana Brown. Original poem.

Filmed by LeChell "The Shootah R.H. @bylechell 

#TexasIsHome #SpokenWordPoet #BlackPoetsOfInstagram #LivePoetry #HTXArtist #SouthernWriters #HoustonArtists #TexasFreeze #SlamPoet #ILoveTheSouth #GalvestonTexas #MyHeritage #EverythingsBiggerInTexas

It is so easy to forget why you started making art in the first place. Especially if you rely on your art to pay your bills! Even for folks who write as a hobby, it is easy to get overwhelmed by the process of trying to get published, trying to improve your skills, and achieve whatever measure of success seems most exciting.

I challenge you to ask yourself: 
—Why do you create and who do you create for?
—Are you still having fun with your writing?
—What would make you more excited to write? Are those things attainable?
—What do you still want to learn?
—How will you make space for your writing and thinking to grow?

Personally, I want to learn to write fiction and get better at sentence structure. I create because it helps me feel connected to myself and this world. When I’m not enjoying the writing anymore, I turn to teaching and being a champion of other people’s writing. I’m learning how to have fun with writing again and remain open to what my peers and students are willing to teach me.

What about you? Does any of this resonate (or challenge) you?

#CreativesOfIG #CreativesOfColor #AdviceForWriters #CreativeWriters #WritingTipsAndTricks #AWritersLife #WritingInspirations #HowToStayMotivated

[ID: Video of Ariana Brown (she/they), a queer Black Mexican American writer based in Houston, TX wearing a black hoodie, hair tied back, with headphones over their ears and a blurred background. She is discussing how she navigates a classroom to be welcoming of people’s  whole selves, which involves care work and accommodating others’ needs.]

#GradSchoolFemtoring #SustainableWriting #MultimodalPedagogies

New Episode! 💜

In this episode of the Grad School Femtoring Podcast, I interview Ariana Brown who discusses the topic of sustainable writing and multimodal pedagogies. 

Ariana Brown is a queer Black Mexican American writer based in Houston, TX. The author of the poetry collections We Are Owed. and Sana Sana, Ariana’s work investigates queer Black personhood in Mexican American spaces, loneliness, and care. She holds a B.A. in African Diaspora Studies and Mexican American Studies, an M.F.A. in Poetry, and M.S. in Library Science. Ariana is a national collegiate poetry slam champion and owes much of her practice to performance communities led by Black women poets from the South. 

In this episode, we cover:

-Common challenges in traditional learning environments and the need for flexibility and understanding

-Multimodal pedagogies and how they can be used to make learning more accessible

-The role that empathy can play in creating more inclusive and supportive classrooms

-And Ariana offers invaluable advice for emerging writers and educators

Listen, subscribe and review the podcast today! 🎧

Feeling so much gratitude lately I can barely contain myself. Swipe for emotional musings, portraits of joy, and a surprise visit from my cat 🐱 

Not to be all “it gets better” because sometimes things suck for a really long time and things are really hard, like unreasonably hard, and I believe in “letting hard things be hard” like my friend Sasha says. I am not interested in pretending. 

But it’s because things were hard for so long that I can experience the depth of gratitude I feel now. Lord knows I wouldn’t pay to relive the last few years. I am simply amazed at how much more life is offering me. I was humbled and then I was leveled and then I stuck a hand out to help myself up and I noticed all the hands of the people I love, reaching out for me. 

Thank you to everyone in my community, everyone who helped me get a job, plan lessons, reminded me to have fun, listened to me read poems, watched a silly show, brought me food, and told me about your day. If I’ve learned anything these last few years, it’s how deeply I am a result of the wonderful people surrounding me.

#MomentsOfGratitude #ThankfulForEverything #CreativeWritingClass #ImATeacher #MyDreamJob #SoSoHappy #ILoveMyCommunity #HoustonTXBaby

I don’t believe in paying full price for most things. If you’ve heard my poem “Ode to Thrift Stores,” you know why! *wink wink* That’s just how I was raised.

That’s one of the reasons I do my best to offer writing classes at a variety of price points. In exactly seven days, I’m offering my most affordable class of the year. Sliding scale donation $25+.

Join us for a one-day virtual writing workshop where we honor our loved ones and the wisdom they instilled in us, by words or by example. We’ll be reading poems by incredible Black female poets, jumping into a supportive group discussion, and closing with plenty of writing and sharing time.

If you’ve been lacking a writing community—you know who you are!—this is the class for you, my friend.

DM me or comment below for more details. Or head to the link in my bio 😊

#SavingMoneyIsFun #DiscountDeals #WritingClass #PoetryClass #ZoomWorkshop #WritingWorkshops #WritingTipsAndTricks #WriterTips #BlackWomenPoets #BlackPoetsOfInstagram #FemalePoets #WomenWriting #MillenialArtist #OnlineLearningCourse #WisdomOfLife #BlackWritersMatter #ReadMorePoetry

Here’s the thing: if you make rushing a central part of your artistic practice, it’s hard to enjoy what you’re making.

What if you could build rest into your practice? Can you identify the moments when you don’t have to rush through the making of something? Look, I get it—we all have deadlines and external pressures. Some things have to be prioritized. But as you do all that rushing and prioritizing, are you allowing yourself to enjoy the moments when you don’t have to rush?

Stillness, rest, play, and social time are JUST as important as getting your work done. This is a lesson I’m constantly learning. My body often makes me pay for it. The older you get and the longer you create art, the more important it is for your artistic practice to be sustainable. Your body will remind you when you’re pushing yourself too far.

This is a gentle reminder to rest when you can. And to take your time. Move at your own pace, if your circumstances allow. Your body and your writing will thank you for it.

For educators and writers! Swipe for generative journal prompts for a free 🇵🇸

I love incorporating journal prompts into my lesson plans as warm up activities. Students often learn best when they are asked to build a personal relationship with the material. This is not to center their experiences in discussion of other marginalized groups, but to ground them before discussing unfamiliar or challenging topics. 

Feel free to share and modify these as best suits your needs. Educators, please keep teaching about Palestine. Please keep introducing students to Palestinian history and the goal of liberation. 

Lesson plans for K-12 educators are available at @teach_palestine and I can’t recommend them enough. 

The writing prompts above are also great for any educator or writer who doesn’t know where to start when educating themselves about this issue. 

In solidarity!

Questions to ask when you’re struggling with self-doubt as a writer ✍️ 

First, know that you aren’t alone. I’ve been writing and teaching poetry for 13 years and I still wonder at times if my writing is “good enough.” Trying to make it as an artist will do that to you when we’re all competing for limited resources re: agents, book deals, viral video views, publishing contests, etc. When you strike out enough times it can feel defeating. Trust me, I know.

So I’m sharing the questions I ask myself when I feel doubtful of my skills as a writer. These questions ground me in my purpose. They remind me that what I write has value regardless if there is a market for it. And trust, there will always be people who want to hear what you have to say. There is always someone who will be moved by your work.

If you’d like supportive feedback on your poems, my upcoming virtual Poetry Workshop class is for you. We’ll meet twice a week on Zoom to learn poetry writing skills, study new writers, and give compassionate, intentional feedback on you and your peers’ work. This is a super small class of only 6 students to ensure you get plenty of attention and helpful feedback.

Comment below if you want details on my upcoming Poetry Workshop virtual class. I’d love to work with you! 😊

I *LOVE* thrift stores because I grew up going to them for almost everything! Being raised by a single mother, we participated in the secondhand economy for almost all our possessions. Weekends in central Texas meant visiting flea markets, yard sales, and thrift stores looking for a deal. To this day, I stand by my grandmother’s advice: “Never pay full price for anything, but if you do, you should love it and it should last you a long time.”

I write poetry about my upbringing to find community with folks who have similar experiences. When I used to perform my spoken word at colleges, people would come up to me after my shows to show off a piece of clothing they had on. They would say things like “I got this for fifty cents at a thrift store!” And they would be so proud. And that’s how I knew I found my people 😂

And honestly, with how expensive groceries are getting, we need to rely more and more on secondhand economies, mutual aid, and community reciprocity to make sure everyone has what they need. Growing up, my mom’s friends and community members would share things with us like toiletries, a place to stay for awhile, extra food, hand-me-downs, knowledge and information about finances that had been systemically kept from us, how to access health care for cheap. I didn’t realize it then, but those practices had a huge impact on me growing up. The working class Mexican women who raised me taught me the power of community, not in an abstract way, but in a practical, tangible way. They weren’t perfect, but this lesson has stayed with me my whole life.

I wrote about these ideas in this excerpt of my poem “Ode to Thrift Stores,” from my book Sana Sana. Link in bio to buy a copy. You can also check out a video of me performing this poem on YouTube.

Share your thrift tips or best thrift store find below!

Or tell me lessons about community care and reciprocity you were taught!
